question: Question_B_06
statement:
There are six neurons connected to a muscle. If four or more of the
neurons fire at the same time, the muscle contracts. In any millisecond,
each neuron has a 0.3 probability of firing. What is the probability
that the muscle contracts in any particular millisecond? You don't have
to simplify your answer.
sols:
(In what follows, the notation \emph{P(outcome)} should be read as ``the
probability that 'outcome' occurs.'')

In order to solve this problem, we need to break it down into pieces. We
are asked to find:

\begin{description}
\itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
\item[]
\emph{P(muscle contracts)}
\end{description}

A muscle contracts if 4 or more neurons fire. Since there are 6 neurons
total we can rewrite this probability as:

\begin{description}
\itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
\item[]
\emph{P(muscle contracts) = P(4, 5, or 6 neurons fire)}
\end{description}

When you have different outcomes joined by an ``or'', you can separate
the outcomes into individual probabilities and add them together. So

\begin{description}
\itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
\item[]
\emph{P(4, 5, or 6 neurons fire) = P(4 neurons fire) + P(5 neurons fire)
+ P(6 neurons fire)}
\end{description}

Hopefully the problem is more manageable now - we're just computing
three individual probabilities and then add them up. Let's start with
the last one, because it's the easiest. (For ease, we will be calling
the six neurons \textbf{a, b, c, d, e} and \textbf{f}.)

\begin{description}
\itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
\item[]
\emph{P(6 neurons fire) = P(\textbf{a} and \textbf{b} and \textbf{c} and
\textbf{d} and \textbf{e} and \textbf{f} fire)}
\end{description}

Recall that when probabilities are joined by an ``and'', you multiply
them. Since the probability of each neuron firing is \emph{.3}, this
means that

\begin{description}
\itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
\item[]
\emph{P(6 neurons fire) = (.3)\textsuperscript{6}}
\end{description}

Now onto the next probability, \emph{P(5 neurons fire)}. Suppose I had a
list of 5 specific neurons I wanted to fire, say \textbf{a} and
\textbf{b} and \textbf{c} and \textbf{d} and \textbf{e}. Since only 5
are firing, this also means the sixth neuron \textbf{f} does not fire,
which has a probability of \emph{.7}. The probability of this specific
combination occurring involves multiplying the probability for each
neuron firing/not firing, which gives
\emph{(.3)\textsuperscript{5}(.7)}. However, this is not the only
combination of 5 neurons that can fire - we need to include all possible
combinations of 5 neurons. This can be done using the binomial
$\binom{6}{5}$. Since the same \emph{(.3)\textsuperscript{5}(.7)}
probability will occur for each list of 5 neurons, our overall
probability is

\begin{description}
\itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
\item[]
\emph{P(5 neurons fire) = $\binom{6}{5}$(.3)\textsuperscript{5}(.7)}
\end{description}

Finally, computing \emph{P(4 neurons fire)}, we use the same method as
the previous probability. The probability that a specific group of 4
neurons will fire is \emph{(.3)\textsuperscript{4}}, the probability
that the other two neurons do not fire is
\emph{(.7)\textsuperscript{2}}, and the number of groups of 4 neurons is
found by the binomial $\binom{6}{4}$, giving

\begin{description}
\itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
\item[]
\emph{P(4 neurons fire) =
$\binom{6}{4}$(.3)\textsuperscript{4}(.7)\textsuperscript{2}}
\end{description}

Since we don't need to simplify any further, we can simply add our
probabilities together as shown above to get a final answer of:

\begin{description}
\itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
\item[]
\emph{P(muscle contracts) = (.3)\textsuperscript{6} +
$\binom{6}{5}$(.3)\textsuperscript{5}(.7)}+
$\binom{6}{4}$(.3)\textsuperscript{4}(.7)\textsuperscript{2}''
\end{description}
hints:
Compute the probability that exactly 6 neurons fire, then exactly 5 then
exactly 4 and add these up. Don't forget that there are many
combinations of exactly 5 neurons firing and exactly 4 neurons firing.
